title: Apple’s all-in-one media bundle faces record-label opposition
text:
The company plans to combine its Apple Music and Apple TV Plus streaming services into a single subscription bundle. Music rights holders are concerned the setup will see them making less money. (Financial Times)

Talking point: Apple’s subscription plan would bring together services with different revenue and growth strategies. The company priced TV Plus at US$4.99 a month, compared to US$8.99 for Netflix’s lowest tier, in order to build audience. Apple can afford to do that in part because it keeps all the revenue—it isn’t licensing other studios’ TV shows and movies to create a content library. On the music side, however, the company has existing relationships with record labels, and historically pays them higher rates than its main rival, Spotify. It launched the service with a built-in base of iTunes users. Combining the two—along with Apple’s Arcade gaming service and News Plus app, both of which require licensing—could prove challenging.
